tit.e: Okamoto no Miya Palace (an ancient Imperial Palace where Emperor Jomei and Empress Saimei lived in seventh century)

sen.j: 岡本宮（おかもとのみや）は、7世紀の舒明天皇及び斉明天皇が営んだ宮。
sen.e: Okamoto no Miya was an Imperial Palace in which Emperor Jomei and Emperor Saimei lived in the seventh century.

sen.j: 舒明天皇の岡本宮は飛鳥岡本宮（あすかのおかもとのみや）、斉明天皇の岡本宮は後飛鳥岡本宮（のちのあすかのおかもとのみや）と区別して呼称される。
sen.e: Okamoto no Miya of Emperor Jomei is called Asuka no Okamoto no Miya and that of Emperor Saimei Nochi no Asuka no Okamoto no Miya to be distinguished.

tit.e: Okamoto no Miya of Emperor Jomei

sen.j: 629年1月に舒明天皇は即位し、翌年（630年）10月、飛鳥岡（雷丘）のふもとに遷宮し、岡本宮と称した。
sen.e: In February 629, Emperor Jomei ascended the throne and in November in the following year (630), moved the Palace to the foot of Asuka no oka (Ikazuchi no oka (The Thunder's Hill)) naming it Okamoto no Miya.

sen.j: その6年後の636年6月、岡本宮は火災で焼失し、舒明天皇は田中宮（たなかのみや、現在の橿原市田中町）へ遷ることとなった。
sen.e: Six years later in July 636, Okamoto no Miya was destroyed by fire and so Emperor Jomei decided to move into Tanaka no Miya in the present Tanaka-cho, Kashihara City).

sen.j: 当時、斉明天皇は多武峰の山頂付近に石塁や高殿を築いたり、奈良盆地に運河を掘るなど、多くの土木事業を営んだが、動員される民衆には非常に不評であった。
sen.e: In those days, Emperor Saimei carried on many construction projects such as building stone mounds and a Takadono (a building placed on the high place) near the top of Tonomine and digging a waterway through the Nara Basin, but these constructions were received unfavorably by the people who were mobilized.
